bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to the Earl of Orkney, May 13, 1727

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to the colony's governor, the Earl of Orkney, May 13, 1727, to report on payment of his salary and a portion of other monies due him, and to enclose bills of exchange (not present) for what is due.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to the Earl of Orkney, May 13, 1727

opener.dateline:
[Lancaster County, ]Virginia
May 13th: 1727
The Rt: honble: Earl of Orkney

div1.p:
I have had the honour Several times
to address my Self to your Lordship am in no doubt yor: Lord
ship has long Since rec'd your bills of Exche: for yor: Salary
from the Death of Collo: Drysdale to the 25th: of Octor: This Acc
ompanys bills of Exche: for Six hundred pounds five hundred pounds thereof drawn by the receiver General on Mr. Perry & Endorsed
by mee the other hundred pound my own Draught on Do:
My own Draught on Mr. The five hundred pounds thereof being
your Lordships Salary to the 25th: of Aprill the One hundred
Pounds for the better half of the perquisites that have yet bin
paid to me The Marriage and Ordinary Lycences are [A]
ccounted for but once a year in October. Mrs. Drysdale recd
them all to our late Govrs: Death as She did the Shipping
fees It is not the Custom of the Naval Officers to make up their
Accots: oftener then every half year and then they account only
for the Vessells that have cleard out These methods Occasion
my being in Possession of no more of the prequisites at
this Time Wee have bin in Expectation of
Leiut. Govr: Colonel Gooch for some Time to whose Arrival I
shall think it my Duty to be accountable to your Lordship

The publick Affairs for his Majestys Service have bin transmitted ac
cording to the Instructions and practice of former Govrs: and
nothing I hope hath bin neglected within the Compass of my Duty
Altho a Crazy health doth Still Attend me I am with the utmost
Duty
div1.closer:
My Lord
Yor: Lordships
Most Oblidged
Most Obedient
& most humble Servt.
per Hopkins
Copy per Woodward

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

[1] Sir William Gooch (1681-1751), lieutenant governor of the colony under the govenor, George Hamilton, Earl of Orkney, would reach Williamsburg in September 1727. He would serve during Carter's lifetime (and until August 1749). (Emily J. Salmon and Edward D. C. Campbell, Jr. The Hornbook of Virginia History.Richmond: The Library of Virginia, 1994. p. 106.)

[2] Captain James Hopkins commanded the Mary in 1727-1728. He was then working for London merchant Robert Cary. He is mentioned in Carter's diary. (Adm. 68/194, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[3] Thomas Woodward commanded the Providence during a number of voyages to the colony, 1723-1727. (Adm. 68/194 and 195, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
